Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing the Recruitment, Retention, Training, and Development of Predominantly Hispanic STEM Majors in the Physical Sciences (Chemistry and Physics)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is focused on three main objectives: (1) to recruit high school students to pursue one of the following S-STEM fields at University of Texas Pan American - a B.S. in Chemistry, a B.S. in Physics, or a B.S. in Physical Science; (2) to promote STEM careers among high school students; and (3) to provide quality training, development, education, and student support services to S-STEM scholars to enable them to persist in their STEM field and finish their degree in a timely manner. Particularly noteworthy is that the project will provide an S-STEM Mentor Training Program that will be aligned with the mentor certification program of the College Reading and Learning Association. This program takes place in South Texas which has a high underrepresented Hispanic population.

Institution.Name: The University of Texas Rio Grande Valley
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of the  project entitled “Enhancing the Recruitment, Retention, Training, and Development of Predominantly Hispanic STEM Majors in the Physical Sciences (Chemistry and Physics)” (NSF DUE Award #: 1154508, April 2012 to March 2019) at the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley (UTRGV)  was to recruit, retain, and train  at least 18 academically talented but financially needy students to pursue any of the following STEM fields: BS in Chemistry, BS in Physics or BS in Physical Science (Chemistry and Physics).

 

The project’s largest accomplishment has been the successful preparation of twenty-four (24) undergraduate students (4 BS Physics and 20 BS Chemistry) who have either continued into graduate school or have gained employment in industries. Results of the external evaluation of the project revealed that the program participants had positive experiences with the program. Generally, the beneficiaries agree that the program met their expectations, was worth their time, was organized and well run. When presented with a list of factors that may have influenced their decision to apply to the S-STEM program, all respondents selected ‘Need for financial support’. Other frequently selected factors include: ‘Explore my interest in STEM’, ‘Improve my research and/or lab skills’ and ‘Determine if being a researcher is an appropriate career path’.

Through funding from the UTRGV S-STEM scholarship, program awardees were provided opportunities to complete their degrees in physics and chemistry. The financial incentive provided by the program was critical to the scholars’ ability to successfully complete their academic program. Program participants came from financially disadvantaged population and the financial support provided an opportunity for them to focus on their studies. In addition, the group and individual mentoring support provided by the project team is an important factor that motivated students to continue and excel in their chosen field. 

Intellectual merit and broader impacts are evident in the way S-STEM scholarships have encouraged and enabled low-income academically talented students in a predominantly Hispanic region to enter the workforce or graduate study following completion of degrees in STEM. Overall, the program is contributing to the development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce.
